image.altText: A group of protesters holding signs demanding the closure of a controversial juvenile detention centre.

props.synopsis: The hearings into the death in custody of a 16-year-old Indigenous boy have revealed some shocking truths, but a lingering question remains for his family and others: What's the point of it all and can it lead to any meaningful change? WARNING: This story contains the name and image of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: Inquest into teen's death in custody lengthy, painful and shocking. Loved ones still have questions

image.altText: A middle aged woman shaking hands with a young school boy. Both are smiling

props.synopsis: The future of public schools will be decided in weeks. Will warring ministers miss the chance to fulfil the promise of the Gonski reforms?

title.children: Stakes high as time left to negotiate public school funding deal ticks down

image.altText: a young man smiling and holding a guitar

props.synopsis: Jetson's parents believe his death was one of the first overdoses to involve nitazene, which is increasingly being found in illicit drugs and counterfeit pharmaceuticals.

title.children: 'He didn't know the risks': Fake pharmaceuticals laced with a deadly synthetic opioid claim young man's life

image.altText: Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant

props.synopsis: The International Atomic Energy Agency warns safety at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in south-eastern Ukraine is deteriorating, after a recent drone strike outside its protection zone.

title.children: Nuclear danger heightens amid military attacks on Europe's largest power facility, IAEA warns

image.altText: A man and a woman wearing hair nets and white coats holding big wheels of cheese.

props.synopsis: Instead of slowing down in retirement, this South West WA couple have started to make and sell their own cheeses from their farm shop.

title.children: Almost-retired couple discover love of cheesemaking after buying kit during COVID

image.altText: Yellow ribbon

props.synopsis: Thousands rally in Israel's largest city demanding Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accept a ceasefire deal, allowing the return of Israeli hostages held in Gaza.

title.children: Large protests staged in Tel Aviv as Israel expresses 'cautious optimism' on Gaza ceasefire

image.altText: Arborists search for signs of the shot-hole borer beetle in Perth's Hyde Park

props.synopsis: Chainsaws are being taken to trees across Perth to stop the spread of shot-hole borer, but scientists say more research is needed to determine if there is a better way to eradicate the pest before beetle activity ramps up come spring.

title.children: Authorities in race against time to stop tiny pest destroying tree canopy before spring ‘explosive phase' begins

image.altText: the mayor of woollahra council in sydney richard shields stands outdoors on a beach cliff

props.synopsis: Liberal sources tell the ABC the "mind-boggling" preselection failure in NSW will motivate the party not to repeat those mistakes in the coming federal election.

title.children: Liberal Party insiders predict 'mind-boggling' preselection failure will see more members sacked

image.altText: A car park full of cars in East Perth.

props.synopsis: It may look like just another car park, but this lot nestled in the heart of East Perth is the battleground for yet another bitter spat between Basil Zempilas and the WA Labor government.

title.children: Parents, children in crossfire in latest spat between Basil Zempilas and WA government

image.altText: Rebecca Zentveld holding coffee beans in her hands.

props.synopsis: The Australian coffee industry is aiming to get bigger and better. Whether it can or not hinges on access to prime real estate and importing smaller coffee trees.

title.children: Australia is getting ready to make a larger play in the multi-billon dollar coffee industry

image.altText: Chen Zi Jun works on a laptop on a narrow timber desk inside her flat, with a streaming camera mounted nearby.

props.synopsis: China's strenuous workplace culture demands intense hours with little time for life, prompting many young people to escape the grind — often without another job lined up or any concrete future plans beyond leaving the rat race.

title.children: Chinese companies demand 'work-life integration'. Young people are 'naked quitting' instead

image.altText: Luke Nolen riding Black Caviar to victory in 2013.

props.synopsis: Tributes continue to flow for champion Australian racehorse Black Caviar — who was unbeaten in 25 races — following her death on Saturday.

title.children: Black Caviar fondly remembered as an 'absolute demon' with a 'beautiful disposition'

image.altText: Jabez Manaika

props.synopsis: The Solomon Islands might seem like an island paradise but beyond the crystal waters not everyone has always felt like they belong. Locals with disability are working through stigma to forge their own path towards a brighter future.

title.children: Jabez was kicked out of school. Now he's making radio history

props.synopsis: Indira Naidoo reported on Timor-Leste for many years as a young journalist. On her first ever visit to the country, with President Ramos-Horta as her guide, Indira discovers the challenges the world's youngest democracy faces and what the future holds.

title.children: Indira Naidoo and the president on a Mini Moke adventure through the world's youngest democracy

image.altText: Baker Boy and bandmates perform onstage at Bluesfest 2019

props.synopsis: As major festivals including Bluesfest, Splendour in the Grass and Groovin the Moo announce cancellations in an industry already on shaky ground, music executives, artists and policymakers have gathered in Darwin to help solve the music industry crisis.

title.children: As music festivals falter, the brightest minds in the industry band together to solve the crisis

image.altText: Hard Quiz host Tom Gleeson smirks behind the podium. The Hard Quiz logo is in the top right corner

props.synopsis: Welcome back, I missed you! Just kidding, that never happens. Let's get on with it, it's time to play, HARD!

title.children: Reckon you could outsmart one of my contestants? Prove it

image.altText: A hand stacking casino chips at a roulette table.

props.synopsis: Thailand's stunning beaches, delicious food and unique cultural heritage are already big drawcards for tourists. Soon the country could add roulette, blackjack and pokies to its list of attractions.

title.children: Why Thailand's move to legalise gambling is a risky bet

image.altText: An Indonesian guy taking a photo with his rental girlfriend in a photobox.

props.synopsis: Imagine a service where you can hire someone to go on a romantic date, hold your hand during a movie, send flirty texts, and even stay on the phone with you until you drift off to sleep. Here is a look at the growing rent-a-partner industry in Indonesia.

title.children: 'Your dream partner': Inside the booming industry of rental girlfriends and boyfriends

image.altText: A large yellow wall in front of two escalators

props.synopsis: The train stations of Sydney's CBD have been little more than grubby pit stops, but those behind the new metro project hope that its gleaming stations with architectural-scale artworks will have commuters looking twice.

title.children: The story behind the art and architecture inside Sydney Metro's new city stations

image.altText: black and white graphic showing old newspaper articles saying slacks banned

props.synopsis: When Dorothy Henderson-Smart based her decision to wear trousers on convenience, little did she know she'd end up making headlines. Years later, her family has uncovered the story of the "girl who shocked Canberra".

title.children: 'The girl who shocked Canberra': Dorothy Henderson-Smart and the fashion choice that sparked a national outcry

image.altText: Patrick Dangerfield walks off with Cats teammates after AFL loss to St Kilda.

props.synopsis: In the wake of a shock loss to St Kilda, Geelong is attempting to quickly get back on track after failing to lock in an AFL top-four berth with a round to go in the home-and-away season.

title.children: 'They're not morons': Defeated Cats moving on from 'missed opportunity' after blowing 33-point lead

image.altText: A group of people protesting. Two women are holding banners, with their fists raised in the air.

props.synopsis: More than 1 million doctors were expected to join the strike, protesting the brutal rape and murder of a female junior doctor in a Kolkata hospital.

title.children: Indian hospitals turn away patients as doctors protest rape and murder of a trainee doctor

image.altText: A sign showing a sign directing people to a polling centre.

props.synopsis: A handful of NT seats, each with roughly 6,000 voters, may determine which party will form government after the August 24 election. Can they go it alone or will they need to negotiate in a hung parliament?

title.children: With the NT election less than a week away, these are the key seats to watch

image.altText: Four people are silhouetted against the backdrop of the moon, which looks massive thanks to a special camera lens

props.synopsis: The night sky will be lit up next week with a bright 'blue' supermoon. Here's what to expect — and why it won't actually have a unique hue.

title.children: Next week will start with a 'blue' supermoon. Here's the best night to see it

image.altText: High school students writing on the white board

props.synopsis: Teenagers face very different high school issues compared to to previous generations. Preparing them for some of the common challenges will make a huge difference in the long term.

title.children: 'Never betray your values to fit in': The advice Bec Sparrow is giving her teenage son as he prepares for high school

image.altText: A huge neoclassical white building is shown with smoke rising behind it

props.synopsis: Authorities said more than 100 firefighters were responding to the blaze at the building that previously housed members of the royal family.

title.children: Flames and smoke billow from historic Somerset House in central London

image.altText: Two men in suits grab each other violently at a lectern while others watch

props.synopsis: An opposition MP's labelling of the government as "terrorists" over the jailing of his fellow MP led to punches being thrown.

title.children: Fistfight breaks out between Turkish MPs in parliament

image.altText: A screenshot from the ABC News opening credits in the 1980s of a satellite hovering around earth

props.synopsis: This week, after a hiatus of 19 years, the old ABC TV News Theme will return to the 7pm bulletins with a fresh lick of paint.

title.children: How a kids' drum kit bought on Gumtree helped teleport the iconic ABC TV News Theme to the present

image.altText: Fusilli pasta with meat bolognese tomato sauce in a plastic box container with a green lid.

props.synopsis: Have you ever tried to triple a recipe and have it go very wrong? Batch cooking can save time during the week, but not all recipes are suitable.

title.children: Why your batch cooking might be failing and how to fix it

image.altText: John Cena and Awkwafina look at something off camera

props.synopsis: The world of Jackpot!, where California civilians are encouraged to murder for lotto money, is only a touch more ridiculous than the script this action comedy tries to pull off.

title.children: Jackpot! doesn't live up to its government-sanctioned murder lotto concept

image.altText: Strawberries growing

props.synopsis: Finding spoiled fruit in your fridge is frustrating but research is underway to make strawberries last longer.

title.children: Why your strawberries are unexpectedly rotting in your fridge

image.altText: Faded yellow old-style boogie board labelled "Nallah's Taxi" and with a smiley face, resting against esky/cooler box with rope

props.synopsis: The off-duty lifesaver used an old boogie board to save four young girls and their dads from treacherous surf.

title.children: How one woman saved six people with a dodgy boogie board

image.altText: Justine Ghekiere celebrates winning Tour de France Femmes stage seven.

props.synopsis: Justine Ghekiere races away from a breakaway group to claim victory in the penultimate stage of the Tour de France Femmes, while Katarzyna Niewiadoma retains the leader's yellow jersey.

title.children: Belgian Ghekiere goes solo to win Tour de France Femmes stage seven

image.altText: Brandon McNulty riding in Vuelta a España.

props.synopsis: Brandon McNulty takes the honours with the fastest time trial in the history of the Spanish Grand Tour race, while Jay Vine is the best-placed Australian after the opening stage.

title.children: American McNulty wins opening Vuelta a España stage, Vine leads Aussie charge

image.altText: Samantha Jade, an attractive blonde throwing a peach up in the air

props.synopsis: Samantha Jade, who calls her new EP "a love letter to love", opens up about her husband and their shared love of music in a wideranging discussion.

title.children: Samantha Jade opens up about love, anxiety, her Indian heritage and portraying Kylie Minogue
